para.text: implement a digital code signing scheme for ensuring the validity and origin of code that has been transmitted across a potentially insecure medium such as the Internet. Code signing and verification is provided by the
package that is installed as part of the WDK.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: The way that code signing works is as follows. When a binary package is exported from the

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: is created and written to a file using the standard Dolphin

Filer. It is this .PAK file that you would distribute if the package was to remain unsigned. However, a signed package is created by reloading the data bytes from the .PAK and then wrapping these within an instance of DolphinSureTrustedData. This signed object is then STB filed out over the top of the original .PAK file. The new signed file contains sufficient information to identify you as the publisher and a "fingerprint" of the package data that can be used by a client to verify that the package contents have not been modified in transit. All of the signature creation and verification process is neatly wrapped within the
